Politician |religion = [[Church of Scotland]]{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2009/sep/23/pope-benedict-to-visit-britain|title=Brown, a member of the Church of Scotland...|date=24 September 2009|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=24 September 2009 | first=Patrick | last=Wintour | location=London}} |signature = Signature of Gordon Brown.png |website = [http://www.gordonbrown.org.uk www.gordonbrown.org.uk] }} '''James Gordon Brown''' (born 20 February 1951) is a [[British people|British]] [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] [[politician]] who was the [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister of the]] [[United Kingdom]] and [[Leader of the Labour Party (UK)|Leader of the]] [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] from [[Labour Party (UK) leadership election, 2007|2007]] until [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|2010]]. He previously served as [[Chancellor of the Exchequer]] in the [[Blair ministry|Labour Government]] from [[United Kingdom general election, 1997|1997]] to [[Labour Party (UK) leadership election, 2007|2007]], becoming the longest-serving holder of that office in modern history. Brown has been a [[Member of Parliament]] (MP) since [[United Kingdom general election, 1983|1983]], for [[Dunfermline East (UK Parliament constituency)|Dunfermline East]] until [[United Kingdom general election, 2005|2005]], and currently for [[Kirkcaldy and Cowdenbeath (UK Parliament constituency)|Kirkcaldy and Cowdenbeath]]. Brown became Prime Minister on 27 June 2007, after the resignation of [[Tony Blair]] and three days after becoming Leader of the governing Labour Party. His tenure ended on 11 May 2010, when he resigned as Prime Minister and Leader of the Labour Party. Brown was one of only three people to serve in the Cabinet continuously from Labour's victory in 1997 until its defeat in 2010, the others being [[Jack Straw]] and [[Alistair Darling]]. Brown has a [[PhD]] in history from the [[University of Edinburgh]] and spent his early career working as a lecturer at a [[further education college]] and a television [[journalist]].{{cite news | url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/programmes/newsnight/4347369.stm | title= Brown seeks out 'British values' | author= Kearney, Martha | date= 14 March 2005 | accessdate= 23 January 2008 | work= BBC News }}{{cite news | url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/6743875.stm | title= The Gordon Brown story | date= 27 June 2007 | accessdate= 11 July 2009 | work= BBC News | publisher= BBC | first=Brian | last=Wheeler}} He has been a Member of Parliament since 1983; first for [[Dunfermline East (UK Parliament constituency)|Dunfermline East]] and since 2005 for Kirkcaldy and Cowdenbeath.{{cite news | url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/6245682.stm | title= Brown is UK's new prime minister | date= 27 June 2007 | accessdate= 23 January 2008 | work= BBC News | publisher= BBC }}{{cite news | url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/shared/mpdb/html/712.stm | title= Gordon Brown | date= 19 November 2007 | accessdate= 23 January 2008 | work= BBC News | publisher= BBC |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070825194726/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/shared/mpdb/html/712.stm |archivedate = August 25, 2007|deadurl=yes}} As Prime Minister, he also held the offices of [[First Lord of the Treasury]] and the [[Minister for the Civil Service]]. Brown's time as Chancellor was marked by major reform of Britain's monetary and fiscal policy architecture, transferring interest rate setting powers to the [[Bank of England]], by a wide extension of the powers of the [[HM Treasury|Treasury]] to cover much domestic policy and by transferring responsibility for banking supervision to the [[Financial Services Authority]].{{cite web | url= http://www.bankofengland.co.uk/financialstability/mou.pdf | title= Memorandum of Understanding between HM Treasury, the Bank of England and the Financial Services Authority | year= 1997| accessdate= 16 July 2009 | work= HM Treasury, Bank of England, FSA | publisher= }} Controversial moves included the abolition of [[advance corporation tax]] (ACT) relief in his first budget,{{cite news|last=Halligan |first=Liam |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1531448/Brown's-raid-on-pensions-costs-Britain-andpound100-billion.html |title=Brown's raid on pensions costs Britain £100 billion |publisher=Telegraph |date=16 October 2006 |accessdate=27 February 2009 | location=London}}{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/business/2002/jul/22/money.politics|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=4 August 2008|title=Pension blame falls on Brown | first=Heather | last=Stewart | date=22 July 2002 | location=London}} and the removal in his final budget of the 10% "starting rate" of personal income tax which he had introduced in 1999.{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/2008/apr/21/economy.labour|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=4 August 2008|title=Q&A: 10p tax rate cut | first=Anil | last=Dawar | date=21 April 2008 | location=London}} After initial rises in opinion polls following Brown's selection as leader, Labour performed poorly in [[United Kingdom local elections, 2009|local and]] [[European Parliament election, 2009|European election results in 2009]].{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=6018|title=New British PM gives party biggest poll lead in two years |publisher=The Philippine Star|accessdate=19 July 2009|date=15 July 2007}}{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article6440935.ece|title=Labour suffers wipeout in its worst local election results|publisher=The Times|accessdate=21 June 2009 | date=6 June 2009 | location=London | first1=Jill | last1=Sherman | first2=Fran | last2=Yeoman | first3=Fiona | last3=Hamilton}}[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/8088133.stm Labour slumps to historic defeat], BBC News, 8 June 2009 A year later, Labour lost 91 seats in the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] at the [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|2010 general election]], the party's biggest loss of seats in a single general election since [[United Kingdom general election, 1931|1931]],{{cite news|url=http://news.scotsman.com/news/General-Election-2010-Gordon39s-career.6279355.jp|title=General Election 2010: Gordon's career is finished – Labour MP|last=Maddox|first=David|date=7 May 2010|work=The Scotsman|accessdate=3 December 2010|location=Edinburgh}} giving the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] a plurality and resulting in a [[hung parliament]].[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/shared/election2010/results/constituency/840.stm General Election 2010 – Kirkcaldy & Cowdenbeath] BBC News[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/election_2010/8667071.stm Election 2010: First hung parliament in UK for decades] BBC News, 7 May 2010 On 10 May 2010, Brown announced he would stand down as leader of the Labour Party, and instructed the party to put into motion the processes to elect a new leader. On 11 May 2010, Brown officially resigned as Prime Minister and Leader of the Labour Party. He was succeeded as Prime Minister by [[David Cameron]],[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/politics/election_2010/8675913.stm Gordon Brown resigns as UK prime minister], [[BBC News]], 11 May 2010 and on [[Labour Party (UK) leadership election, 2010|25 September 2010]], he was succeeded as Leader of the Labour Party by [[Ed Miliband]]. ==Early life and career before Parliament== Gordon Brown was born at the Orchard Maternity Nursing Home in [[Giffnock]], [[Renfrewshire (historic)|Renfrewshire]], Scotland.{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/i-could-still-be-prime-minister-says-brown-1137937.html|title=I could still be prime minister, says Brown |publisher=The Independent|date=19 January 1998|accessdate=12 February 2010 | first=Paul | last=Routledge | location=London}}Birth certificate of James Gordon Brown, 20 February 1951, Newton Mearns District, Renfrewshire 571/02 0053 – General Register Office for Scotland His father was John Ebenezer Brown, a [[Ministers and elders in the Church of Scotland|minister]] of the [[Church of Scotland]] and a strong influence on Brown. He died in December 1998, aged 84.{{cite news|title=Chancellor's daughter remembered at christening service|publisher=The Scotsman|date=23 April 2004|accessdate=23 September 2007|url=http://news.scotsman.com/topics.cfm?tid=110&id=455352004|location=Edinburgh}} {{Dead link|date=February 2011|bot=RjwilmsiBot}} His mother Jessie Elizabeth Souter, known as Bunty, died on 19 September 2004, aged 86.{{cite news|title = Brown mourns loss of mother|publisher =The Scotsman|date = 20 September 2004|accessdate = 23 September 2007|url = http://news.scotsman.com/topics.cfm?tid=110&id=1102842004|location=Edinburgh}} {{Dead link|date=February 2011|bot=RjwilmsiBot}} She was the daughter of John Souter, a timber merchant.{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/portal/main.jhtml?xml=/portal/2007/04/28/nosplit/ftfamdet128.xml|title=Family detective | work=The Daily Telegraph | first=Nick | last=Barratt | date=28 April 2007 | accessdate=2 April 2010 | location=London}} Brown was brought up with his elder brother John and younger brother [[Andrew Brown (media strategist)|Andrew Brown]] in a [[manse]] in [[Kirkcaldy]] — the largest town in [[Fife]], Scotland across the [[Firth of Forth]] from [[Edinburgh]].{{cite news|title = From a Scottish manse to Number 10|publisher =The Washington Times|date = 14 July 2007|accessdate = 23 September 2007|url = http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2007/jun/17/from-a-scottish-manse-to-number-10/}} In common with many other [[notable Scots]], he is therefore often referred to as a "son of the manse".{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1554039/The-making-of-Gordon-Brown.html|title=The making of Gordon Brown|quote=The next prime minister is always referred to as a 'son of the manse'|publisher=The Telegraph|date=9 June 2007|accessdate=27 December 2009 | location=London}} Brown was educated first at Kirkcaldy West Primary School where he was selected for an experimental [[Ability grouping|fast stream]] education programme, which took him two years early to [[Kirkcaldy High School]] for an academic [[hothousing|hothouse education]] taught in separate classes.{{cite news|title = Chancellor on the ropes; Profile: Gordon Brown|publisher =The Independent |date = 23 September 2000|accessdate = 21 June 2009|url =http://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/chancellor-on-the-ropes-701085.html | first=Donald | last=MacIntyre | location=London}} At age sixteen he wrote that he loathed and resented this "ludicrous" experiment on young lives.{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/politics/article1811255.ece|title=‘Cruel’ experiment that left its mark on a very precocious boy|author=Ben Macintyre|publisher=The Times|date=19 May 2007|accessdate=13 July 2007 | location=London}} He was accepted by the [[University of Edinburgh]] to study history at the same early age of sixteen. During an end-of-term [[rugby union]] match at his old school he received a kick to the head and suffered a [[retinal detachment]]. This left him [[Blindness|blind]] in his left eye, despite treatment including several operations and weeks spent lying in a darkened room. Later at Edinburgh, while playing tennis, he noticed the same symptoms in his right eye. Brown underwent experimental surgery at [[Edinburgh Royal Infirmary]] and his right eye was saved.{{cite news |first=Suzie |last=Mackenzie |title=Will he? Won't he? |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/2004/sep/25/interviews.labourconference |work=[[The Guardian]] |publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]] |date=25 September 2004 |accessdate=1 March 2008 | location=London}} Brown graduated from Edinburgh with [[First Class Honours]] [[Master of Arts (Scotland)|MA]] in history in 1972, and stayed on to complete his PhD in history (which he gained ten years later in 1982), titled ''The Labour Party and Political Change in Scotland 1918–29''.{{cite web|title=History and tour-Gordon Brown| url=http://www.number10.gov.uk/history-and-tour/prime-ministers-in-history/gordon-brown| accessdate= 21 June 2009|publisher=Prime Minister's Office}}{{cite news|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=70vRFO9Mo6oC&pg=PA262&lpg=PA262&dq=%22the+labour+party+and+political+change+in+scotland%22+1982&source=web&ots=0h5Nh_Dhyd&sig=Ky6m7yB5eMixfMyFBExxOVEKHnc|title=State of the Union: Unionism and the Alternatives in the United Kingdom|author=Iain MacLean, Alistair MacMillan|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|year=2005|accessdate=23 September 2007}} In 1972, while still a student, Brown was elected [[Rector of the University of Edinburgh]], the convener of the [[University Court]].[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/4683799.stm Brown's first taste of power] BBC News, 15 July 2005 He served as Rector until 1975, and also edited the document ''The Red Paper on Scotland''.{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/2000/nov/05/scotlanddevolution.devolution|title=Life on the ante-eurodiluvian Left|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=16 July 2009|date=5 October 2000 | first=Neal | last=Ascherson | location=London}} From 1976 to 1980 Brown was employed as a [[lecturer]] in politics at [[Glasgow Caledonian University|Glasgow College of Technology]]. In the [[United Kingdom general election, 1979|1979 general election]], he stood for the [[Edinburgh South (UK Parliament constituency)|Edinburgh South]] constituency, losing to the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] candidate, [[Michael Ancram]]. From 1980 he worked as a journalist at [[Scottish Television]], later serving as current affairs editor until his election to parliament in 1983.[http://www.isj.org.uk/index.php4?id=334&issue=115 "Brown's Journey from Reformism to Neoliberalism"] John Newsinger [[International Socialism (journal)|International Socialism]] 115 (summer 2007) He also worked as a tutor for the [[Open University]].{{cite web|url=http://www.politics.co.uk/news/business-and-industry/gordon-browns-tuc-speech-in-full-$478186.htm |title=Gordon Brown's TUC speech in full (to the 2007 TUC Congress) |publisher=politics.co.uk |date=10 September 2007|accessdate=13 April 2010}} ==Election to parliament and opposition== Gordon Brown was elected to Parliament on his second attempt as a Labour MP for [[Dunfermline East (UK Parliament constituency)|Dunfermline East]] in [[United Kingdom general election, 1983|1983 general election]]. His first Westminster office mate was a newly elected MP from the Sedgefield constituency by the name of [[Tony Blair]]. Brown became an [[opposition (government)|opposition]] spokesman on Trade and Industry in 1985. In 1986, he published a [[biography]] of the [[Independent Labour Party]] politician [[James Maxton]], the subject of his PhD thesis. Brown was [[Shadow Cabinet|Shadow]] [[Chief Secretary to the Treasury]] from 1987 to 1989 and then Shadow [[Secretary of State for Trade and Industry]], before becoming Shadow Chancellor in 1992. Having led the ''Labour Movement Yes'' campaign, refusing to join the cross-party ''Yes for Scotland'' campaign, during the [[1979 Scottish devolution referendum]], while other senior Labour politicians — including [[Robin Cook]], [[Tam Dalyell]] and [[Brian Wilson (Labour politician)|Brian Wilson]] – campaigned for a ''No'' vote, Brown was subsequently a key participant in the [[Scottish Constitutional Convention]], signing the [[Claim of Right for Scotland]] in 1989.{{cite news |first=Kenyon |last=Wright |authorlink= Canon Kenyon Wright |url= http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4156/is_19990404/ai_n13938013 |title=Scotland can sing a new song to a different tune and in a clear voice |publisher=Sunday Herald |date= 4 April 1999 |accessdate= 1 March 2008 |quote=... the Claim of Right of Scotland. I have it before me now as I write — a note of sadness as I see that the first two signatures, side by side, are those of the late John Smith MP and myself, a note of gratified surprise to see these closely followed by the autographs of Gordon Brown, Robin Cook, George Robertson, Donald Dewar, Malcolm Bruce, Jim Wallace and, more important, an impressive cross-section of Scotland's civil society.}} After the sudden death of Labour leader [[John Smith (UK politician)|John Smith]] in May 1994, Brown did not contest the leadership after [[Tony Blair]] became favourite, deciding to make way for Tony Blair to avoiding splitting the pro-modernising vote in the leadership ballot.[http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/historic_figures/blair_tony.shtml] It has long been rumoured [[Blair-Brown deal|a deal]] was struck between Blair and Brown at the former [[Granita (restaurant)|Granita restaurant]] in [[A1 road (London)#Upper Street|Islington]], in which Blair promised to give Brown control of economic policy in return for Brown not standing against him in the [[Labour Party (UK) leadership election, 1994|leadership election]].{{cite news |first=Michael |last=White |authorlink=Michael White (journalist) |title=The guarantee which came to dominate new Labour politics for a decade |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/2003/jun/06/uk.labour |work=[[The Guardian]] |publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]] |date= 6 June 2003|accessdate=1 March 2008 | location=London}}{{cite news |first=Catherine |last=Mayer |authorlink=Catherine Mayer |title=Fight Club |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,901050124-1018039-2,00.html |work=Time Magazine |date=16 January 2005 |accessdate=1 March 2008 }} Whether this is true or not, the relationship between Blair and Brown has been central to the fortunes of "[[Labour Party (UK)#"New Labour" – in government (1997–2010)|New Labour]]", and they have mostly remained united in public, despite reported serious private rifts.{{cite news |first=Brian |last=Wheeler |title=The Tony Blair story |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/6506365.stm |work=BBC News |date=10 May 2007 |accessdate=1 March 2008 }} As Shadow Chancellor, Brown as Chancellor-in-waiting was seen as a good choice by business and the middle class. While he was Chancellor inflation sometimes exceeded the 2% target causing the [[Governor of the Bank of England]] to write several letters to the Chancellor, each time inflation exceeded three per cent.{{cite web|url=http://www.statistics.gov.uk/cci/nugget.asp?ID=19 |title=Inflation |publisher=National Statistics Online|date= |accessdate=13 April 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.statistics.gov.uk/cci/nugget.asp?ID=12 |title=Employment|publisher=National Statistics Online |date=17 March 2010 |accessdate=13 April 2010}} In 2005 following a reorganisation of [[List of UK Parliamentary constituencies in Scotland|parliamentary constituencies]] in Scotland, Brown became MP for [[Kirkcaldy and Cowdenbeath (UK Parliament constituency)|Kirkcaldy and Cowdenbeath]] at the [[United Kingdom general election, 2005|general election]].{{cite news|url=http://politics.guardian.co.uk/hoc/constituency/0,9338,-1059,00.html|title=The Guardian 2005 election results for Kirkcaldy and Cowdenbeath | accessdate=2 April 2010 | location=London}} ==Chancellor of the Exchequer== {{Main|Chancellorship of Gordon Brown}} In the [[United Kingdom general election, 1997|1997 general election]], Labour defeated the Conservatives by a landslide to end their 18-year exile from government on when [[Tony Blair]], the new prime minister, announced his ministerial team on 2 May 1997, he appointed Brown as [[Chancellor of the Exchequer]]. He would remain in this role for 10 years and two months, making him the longest-serving Chancellor in modern history. The Prime Minister's website highlights some achievements from Brown's decade as Chancellor: making the Bank of England independent and delivering an agreement on poverty and climate change at the [[G8]] summit in 2005. [[File:Gordon Brown IMF.jpg|thumb|Gordon Brown speaking at the annual [[World Bank]]/[[International Monetary Fund|IMF]] meeting in 2002|alt=Gordon Brown standing at a [[podium]]. Text on the podium states "ANNUAL MEETINGS". A number of flags hang in the background]] ===Early economic reforms=== On taking office as [[Chancellor of the Exchequer]] Brown gave the [[Bank of England]] operational independence in [[monetary policy]], and thus responsibility for setting [[interest rate]]s through the Bank's [[Monetary Policy Committee]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/low/business/2002471.stm |title=Five years on: Rating the MPC|publisher=BBC News |accessdate=21 June 2009 | date=6 June 2002 | first=Steve | last=Schifferes}} At the same time he also changed the [[inflation rate|inflation measure]] from the [[Retail Prices Index (United Kingdom)|Retail Price Index]] to the [[Consumer Price Index]] and transferred responsibility for banking supervision to the [[Financial Services Authority]].{{cite web|url=http://archive.treasury.gov.uk/press/1997/p40_97.html |title=Chancellor announces new framework for monetary policy|publisher=HM Treasury |date=6 May 1997 |accessdate=27 February 2009}} Some commentators have argued that this division of responsibilities exacerbated the severity, in Britain, of 2007 global banking crisis.{{cite news|url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/banking_and_finance/article6410087.ece|title= Gordon Brown and Treasury accused on banking crisis|publisher=Times Online|accessdate=19 July 2009|date=2 June 2009 | first=Patrick | last=Hosking | location=London}} ===Taxation and spending=== In the 1997 election and subsequently, Brown pledged to not increase the basic or higher rates of [[income tax]]. Over his Chancellorship, he reduced the basic rate from 23% to 20%. However, in all but his final budget, Brown increased the tax thresholds in line with inflation, rather than earnings, resulting in [[fiscal drag]]. [[Corporation tax]] fell under Brown, from a main rate of 33% to 28%, and from 24% to 19% for [[small business]]es.Adam, S. and J. Browne: {{PDFlink|[http://www.ifs.org.uk/bns/bn09.pdf A survey of the UK tax system]|2.74 MB}} ([http://72.14.221.104/u/ifs?q=cache:wlXNSdRqqg8J:www.ifs.org.uk/bns/bn09.pdf+uk+tax+system Google cache HTML]), [[Institute for Fiscal Studies]], [[Briefing note]] No. 9, March 2006 In 1999, he introduced a lower tax band of 10%. He abolished this [[Alistair Darling#10% income tax band|10% tax band]] in his last budget in 2007 to reduce the basic rate from 22% to 20%, increasing tax for 5 million people{{cite news |url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/brown-faces-revolt-over-scrapping-10p-income-tax-band-804528.html?r=RSS |publisher=[[The Independent]] |title=Brown faces revolt over scrapping 10p income tax band |first=Andrew |last=Grice |date=4 April 2008 |accessdate=20 April 2008 | location=London}} and, according to the calculations of the [[Institute for Fiscal Studies]], leaving those earning between £5,000 and £18,000 as the biggest losers.{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/politics/article3779976.ece |publisher=[[The Sunday Times]] |date=20 April 2008 |title=Gordon Brown cornered as rebellion over 10p tax reform grows |author=Isabel Oakeshott and David Leppard |accessdate=15 July 2009 | location=London}} According to the [[Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development|OECD]] UK taxation has increased from a 39.3% share of [[gross domestic product]] in 1997 to 42.4% in 2006, going to a higher level than Germany.OECD: [http://www.oecd.org/dataoecd/5/51/2483816.xls General Government Outlays as percentage of GDP] ([[Microsoft Office Excel]] table) This increase has mainly been attributed to active government policy, and not simply to the growing economy. Conservatives have accused Brown of imposing "[[stealth tax]]es". A commonly reported example resulted in 1997 from a technical change in the way [[corporation tax]] is collected, the indirect effect of which was for the [[dividend]]s on [[stock]] investments held within [[pension]]s to be taxed, thus lowering pension returns and contributing to the demise of most of the final salary pension funds in the UK.{{cite news |first=Liam |last=Halligan |authorlink=Liam Halligan |title=Brown's raid on pensions costs Britain £100 billion |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2006/10/15/nbrown15.xml |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=16 October 2006 |accessdate=1 March 2008 | location=London}} The Treasury contends that this tax change was crucial to long-term economic growth. Brown's 2000 Spending Review outlined a major expansion of [[government spending]], particularly on health and education. In his April 2002 budget, Brown increased [[national insurance]] to pay for health spending. He also introduced [[working tax credit]]s.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/5032170.stm More get tax credit overpayments] BBC News, 31 May 2006[http://www.ifs.org.uk/bns/bn52.pdf#search=%22working%20tax%20credit%2016%20hours%22 The impact of tax and benefit changes between April 2000 and April 2003 on parents' labour supply] Blundell, R., M. Brewer and A. Shepherd, [[Institute for Fiscal Studies]], Briefing Note No. 52, 2004 ===European single currency=== In October 1997, Brown took control of the United Kingdom's membership of the European single currency issue by announcing the Treasury would set [[five economic tests]]{{cite news |first=Julian |last=Glover |title=The five tests |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/business/2000/sep/29/emu.theeuro4 |work=[[The Guardian]] |publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]] |date=29 September 2000 |accessdate=1 March 2008 | location=London}} to ascertain whether the economic case had been made. In June 2003 [[HM Treasury|the Treasury]] indicated the tests had not been passed.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/2975560.stm UK 'not yet ready for the euro'] BBC News, 9 June 2003 ===Other issues=== In 2000, Brown was accused of starting a political row about higher education (referred to as the [[Laura Spence Affair]]) when he accused the University of Oxford of elitism in its admissions procedures, describing its decision not to offer a place to [[state school]] pupil Laura Spence as "absolutely outrageous".{{cite news| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/764141.stm| title = Oxford 'reject' wins Harvard scholarship| accessdate = 30 March 2007| date = 22 May 2000| work = BBC News| publisher = BBC}} [[Roy Jenkins|Lord Jenkins]], then Oxford [[Chancellor (education)|Chancellor]] and himself a former Labour Chancellor of the Exchequer, said "nearly every fact he used was false."{{cite news| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/792021.stm| title = Peers condemn Oxford attack| accessdate = 30 March 2007| date = 15 June 2000| work = BBC News| publisher = BBC}} Between 1999 and 2002 Brown sold 60% of the UK's [[gold reserves]] shortly before gold entered a protracted bull market, since nicknamed by dealers as [[Brown Bottom]].[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/politics/article1655001.ece Goldfinger Brown's £2 billion blunder in the bullion market, ''The Times'', 15 April 2007]{{dead link|date=November 2010}}{{cite news|author=11:39AM GMT 19 December 2008 Comments |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/personalfinance/investing/3849910/The-outlook-for-gold.html |title=The outlook for gold |publisher=Telegraph.co.uk |date=19 December 2008 |accessdate=19 November 2010 |location=London}}{{cite web|author=Clive Maund |url=http://www.marketoracle.co.uk/Article670.html |title=The Gold Bull Market Remembers How Gordon Brown Sold Half of Britains Reserves at the Lowest Price |publisher=Marketoracle.co.uk |date=1 April 2007 |accessdate=19 November 2010}} The official reason for selling the gold reserves was to reduce the [[Financial risk|portfolio risk]] of the UK's reserves by diversifying away from gold.{{Cite document|url=http://hm-treasury.gov.uk/d/GoldReserves.PDF|date=October 2002|title=Review of the sale of part of the UK gold reserves|page=7|publisher=[[HM Treasury]]|postscript=}} The UK eventually sold about 395 tons of gold over 17 auctions from July 1999 to March 2002, at an average price of about US$275 per ounce, raising approximately US$3.5 billion.^ a b c Gold: Does Gordon Brown's regret selling half of Britains' gold reserves 10 years ago?, The Daily Telegraph, 8 May 2009 By 2011, that quantity of gold would be worth over $19 billion, leading to Brown's decision to sell the gold being widely criticised.{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/politics/article1655001.ece|title=Goldfinger Brown's £2 billion blunder in the bullion market|publisher=Times Online|accessdate=19 July 2009|date=15 April 2007 | first1=Holly | last1=Watt | first2=Robert | last2=Winnett | location=London}} During his time as Chancellor, Brown reportedly believed that it was appropriate to remove most, but not all, of the unpayable [[Third World debt]].{{cite news |title=Gordon Brown answers your questions |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/369846.stm |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=15 June 1999 |accessdate=1 March 2008 }} On 20 April 2006, in a speech to the United Nations [[Ambassador]]s, Brown outlined a "[[Green politics|Green]]" view of global development.{{cite web|url=http://www.hm-treasury.gov.uk/speech_chex_200406.htm|url=http://www.hm-treasury.gov.uk/speech_chex_200406.htm|title=Gordon Brown's speech, to United Nations Ambassadors, New York, 20 April 2006|publisher=H.M. Treasury|accessdate=17 October 2009}} During his time as Chancellor, Brown supervised the [[Spectrum_auction|Telecoms Spectrum auctions]]; this raised 22.5 Billion [http://www.guardian.co.uk/comment/story/0,,178157,00.html Dial-a-fortune | Guardian daily comment | guardian.co.uk] ==Run-up to succeeding Tony Blair== :''Main articles [[Labour Party (UK) leadership election, 2007|Labour Party leadership election, 2007]] and [[Timeline for the Labour Party (UK) leadership elections, 2007|Timeline for the Labour Party leadership elections, 2007]] In October 2004, [[Tony Blair]] announced he would not lead the party into a fourth [[general election]], but would serve a full third term.{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/2004/oct/01/uk.labourconference2|title=Blair: I will serve a full third term|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=19 July 2009|date=21 October 2004 | first=Michael | last=White | location=London}} Political comment over the relationship between Brown and Blair continued up to and beyond the [[United Kingdom general election, 2005|2005 election]], which Labour won with a reduced parliamentary majority and reduced vote share. Blair announced on 7 September 2006 that he would step down within a year.{{cite news | first = Alan | last = Cowell|authorlink=Alan Cowell | title = Blair to Give Up Post as Premier Within One Year|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2006/09/08/world/europe/08blair.html?ex=1315368000&en=5e7bcfe77c01e050&ei=5088 |date = 8 September 2006 | work = The New York Times | publisher = [[The New York Times Company]] |accessdate = 10 July 2007 }} Brown was the clear favourite to succeed Blair; he was the only [[Labour Party (UK) leadership election, 2007|candidate]] spoken of seriously in Westminster. Appearances and news coverage leading up to the handover were interpreted as preparing the ground for Brown to become [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]], in part by creating the impression of a statesman with a vision for leadership and [[global change]]. This enabled Brown to signal the most significant priorities for his agenda as Prime Minister; speaking at a [[Fabian Society]] conference on 'The Next Decade' in January 2007, he stressed education, international development, narrowing inequalities (to pursue 'equality of opportunity and fairness of outcome'), renewing Britishness, restoring trust in politics, and winning hearts and minds in the war on terror as key priorities.{{cite press release |title = Make education our national mission |publisher = [[Fabian Society]] | date = 15 January 2007 |url= http://www.fabian-society.org.uk/events/event-reports/brown-make-education-our-national-mission|accessdate= 21 June 2009}} ==Prime Minister== {{Main|Premiership of Gordon Brown}} Brown ceased to be Chancellor and became the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom on 27 June 2007. Like all modern Prime Ministers, Brown concurrently served as the [[First Lord of the Treasury]] and the [[Minister for the Civil Service]], and was a member of the [[Cabinet of the United Kingdom]]. Until his resignation from the post in May 2010 he was [[Labour Party (UK)#Leaders of the Labour Party since 1906|Leader of the Labour Party]]. He is Member of Parliament for the constituency of [[Kirkcaldy and Cowdenbeath (UK Parliament constituency)|Kirkcaldy and Cowdenbeath]]. He is the sixth post-war prime minister, of a total of 12, to assume the role without having won a general election.{{cite web|author=O'Connor, John Kennedy|title=Brown's Ascendency|publisher=ABC Radio National Perspective|date=25 June 2007|url=http://www.abc.net.au/rn/perspective/stories/2007/1960948.htm|accessdate=15 July 2009}} Brown was the first prime minister from a Scottish constituency since the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] [[Alec Douglas-Home|Sir Alec Douglas-Home]] in 1964. Not all British prime ministers have attended university, but of the ones that did Brown was one of only five that did not attend either Oxford or Cambridge, the others were, [[John Stuart, 3rd Earl of Bute|the Earl of Bute]] ([[University of Leiden|Leiden]]), [[John Russell, 1st Earl Russell|Lord John Russell]] ([[University of Edinburgh|Edinburgh]]), [[Bonar Law|Andrew Bonar Law]] ([[University of Glasgow]]), and [[Neville Chamberlain]] ([[Mason Science College]], later [[University of Birmingham|Birmingham]]).{{cite web |url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/dna/h2g2/A4197440 | title = Are you Statistically Prepared to Become Prime Minister of the United Kingdom? | accessdate=30 March 2007 | date = 1 August 2005 | work = h2g2 | publisher = BBC }} Brown proposed moving some traditional prime ministerial powers conferred by [[royal prerogative]] to the realm of Parliament, such as the power to declare war and approve appointments to senior positions. Brown wanted Parliament to gain the right to ratify treaties and have more oversight into the intelligence services. He also proposed moving some powers from Parliament to citizens, including the right to form "citizens' juries", easily petition Parliament for new laws, and rally outside Westminster. He asserted that the attorney general should not have the right to decide whether to prosecute in individual cases, such as in the [[Cash for Peerages|loans for peerages]] scandal.{{cite news | title = Gordon Brown's big idea|url=http://www.economist.com/world/britain/displaystory.cfm?story_id=9441642|publisher =The Economist|date=5 July 2007|accessdate=15 July 2009}} During his Labour leadership campaign Brown proposed some policy initiatives which he called 'The manifesto for change.'{{cite news | title = Gordon's manifesto for change | url = http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/politics/article1782142.ece | work = The Times | date = 13 May 2007 | accessdate = 15 July 2009 | location=London | first=Deirdre | last=Hipwell}}{{cite news | title = Poll surge as Brown unveils policy blitz | url = http://observer.guardian.co.uk/politics/story/0,,2078595,00.html | work = The Observer|date= 13 May 2007 | location=London | first=Nicholas | last=Watt | accessdate=2 April 2010}} The manifesto included a clampdown on corruption and a new [[Ministerial Code]], which set out clear standards of behaviour for ministers.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/6258794.stm|date=3 July 2007|accessdate=3 August 2008|publisher=BBC News|title=Brown sets out reform proposals}} Brown also stated in a speech when announcing his bid that he wants a "better constitution" that is "clear about the rights and responsibilities of being a citizen in Britain today". He planned to set up an all-party convention to look at new powers for Parliament and to look at rebalancing powers between [[Whitehall]] and local government. Brown said he would give Parliament the final say on whether British troops are sent into action in future. Brown said he wanted to release more land and ease access to ownership with shared equity schemes. He backed a proposal to build new [[Eco-towns (UK)|eco-towns]], each housing between 10,000 and 20,000 home-owners — up to 100,000 new homes in total. Brown also said he wanted to have doctors' surgeries open at the weekends, and GPs on call in the evenings. Doctors were given the right of opting out of out-of-hours care in 2007, under a controversial pay deal, signed by then-Health Secretary [[John Reid (politician)|John Reid]], which awarded them a 22% pay rise in 2006. Brown also stated in the manifesto that the NHS was his top priority. There was speculation during September and early October 2007 about whether Brown would call a [[snap election|snap general election]]. Brown announced at the time that there would be no [[United Kingdom general election|election]] any time soon - despite opinion polls showing that he was capable of winning an election should he call one. However, this proved to be a costly mistake, as during 2008 his party slid behind the Conservatives (led by David Cameron) in the polls. Disputes over political donations, a string of losses in local elections, and by-election losses in [[Crewe]] and [[Glasgow]] did himself and the government no favours either.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/election_2010/8673608.stm | work=BBC News | first=James | last=Landale | title=Gordon Brown's political career | date=11 May 2010}} His political opponents accused him of being indecisive, which Brown denied.{{cite news | title=Brown rules out autumn election | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7031749.stm | publisher=BBC News|accessdate= 6 October 2007 | date=6 October 2007}} In July 2008 Brown supported a [[Counter-Terrorism Bill 2008|new bill extending this pre-charge detention period to 42 days]]. The bill was met with opposition on both sides of the House and backbench rebellion. In the end the bill passed by just 9 votes.{{cite news | title=Labour denies Keith Vaz offered 'reward' for backing government | url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/politics/article4257007.ece | accessdate= 2 July 2008| date=2 July 2008 | first=Philip | last=Webster | location=London | work=The Times}}{{cite news | title=There were no deals over 42 day vote, insists Brown | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/2008/jun/12/terrorism.labour | accessdate= 12 June 2008 | publisher=The Guardian| first=Patrick | last=Wintour | date=12 June 2008 | location=London}} The House of Lords defeated the bill, with Lords characterising it as "fatally flawed, ill thought through and unnecessary", stating that "it seeks to further erode fundamental legal and civil rights".[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/politics/lawandorder/3192152/Jacqui-Smith-creates-emergency-bill-after-42-day-detention-defeat.html Jacqui Smith creates 'emergency bill' after 42-day detention defeat], ''The Daily Telegraph'', 14 October 2008 Brown was mentioned by the press in the expenses crisis for claiming for the payment of his cleaner. However, no wrongdoing was found and the Commons Authority did not pursue Brown over the claim. Meanwhile, the Commons Fees Office stated that a double payment for a £153 plumbing repair bill was a mistake on their part and that Brown had repaid it in full.{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/2009/may/10/gordon-brown-cleaner-mps-expenses |title=MPs' expenses: the true story of Gordon Brown, the cleaner and my husband |publisher=The Guardian |accessdate=13 May 2009 | date=10 May 2009 | location=London}}{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/8039273.stm |title=MPs' expenses claims — key details |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=13 May 2009 | date=19 June 2009}} ===Foreign policy=== [[File:President Barack Obama meets Prime Minister Gordon Brown.jpg|thumb|240px|right|Gordon Brown and President [[Barack Obama]] meet in the [[White House]]]] Brown was committed to the [[Iraq War]], but said in a speech in June 2007 that he would "learn the lessons" from the mistakes made in Iraq.{{cite news | first=George | last=Jones | coauthors= | title=The subtle shift in British foreign policy | date=12 June 2007 | publisher= | url =http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2007/06/11/wbrown111.xml | work =Telegraph.co.uk | pages = | accessdate = 23 September 2007 | language = | location=London}} Brown said in a letter published on 17 March 2008 that the United Kingdom would hold an inquiry into the [[Iraq war]].{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/there-will-be-a-public-inquiry-into-iraq-says-brown-796851.html|title= There will be a public inquiry into Iraq, says Brown|publisher=The Independent|accessdate=19 July 2009|date=17 March 2008 | location=London | first1=Andrew | last1=Grice | first2=Nigel | last2=Morris}} He is also a member of the lobby group, [[Labour Friends of Israel]].Assaf Uni, [http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/932399.html Finance scandal has local community worried], [[Haaretz]], December 10, 2007.Ned Temko, [http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/2007/dec/02/uk.partyfunding1 Behind-the-scenes group's unerring knack of backing the right man], [[The Guardian]], December 2, 2007.{{cite web | title=Speech by Gordon Brown to the LFI Annual Reception| date=September 25, 2007| author=Brown, Gordon | publisher=Labor Friends of Israel | url=http://www.lfi.org.uk/news///Speech_by_Gordon_Brown}} Brown went to great lengths to empathise with those who lost family members in the Iraq and Afghanistan conflicts. He has often said "War is tragic", echoing Blair's memorable quote, "War is horrible".{{cite news | author = Dougary, Ginny | authorlink = Ginny Dougary | title = What Gordon Brown is really thinking | work = The Times | date = 10 April 2010 | url = http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/politics/article7088875.ece | accessdate = 27 April 2010 | location=London}} Nonetheless, in November 2007 Brown was accused by some senior military figures of not adhering to the '[[military covenant]]', a convention within British politics insuring adequate safeguards, rewards and compensation for military personnel who risk their lives in obedience to orders derived from the policy of the elected government.{{cite news | title=Renew the Military Covenant | publisher=The Independent|url=http://comment.independent.co.uk/leading_articles/article3149962.ece | accessdate= 11 November 2007 | location=London | date=11 November 2007}} Brown skipped the opening ceremony of the [[2008 Summer Olympics]], on 8 August 2008 in Beijing. He attended the closing ceremony instead, on 24 August 2008. Brown had been under intense pressure from human rights campaigners to send a message to China, concerning the [[2008 Tibetan unrest]]. His decision not to attend the opening ceremony was not an act of protest, but rather was made several weeks in advance and not intended as a stand on principle.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7339580.stm|title=PM not attending Olympics opening|accessdate=19 July 2009|publisher=BBC News|date=10 April 2008 }} In a speech in July 2007, Brown personally clarified his position regarding Britain's relationship with the USA{{cite news|title=Speech not critical of US — Brown|publisher=BBC News|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/6896797.stm|accessdate = 14 July 2007 | date=13 July 2007}} "We will not allow people to separate us from the United States of America in dealing with the common challenges that we face around the world. I think people have got to remember that the special relationship between a British prime minister and an American president is built on the things that we share, the same enduring values about the importance of liberty, opportunity, the dignity of the individual. I will continue to work, as Tony Blair did, very closely with the American administration." Brown and the Labour party had pledged to allow a referendum on the EU [[Treaty of Lisbon]]. On the morning of 13 December 2007, Foreign Secretary [[David Miliband]] attended for the Prime Minister at the official signing ceremony in Lisbon of the [[EU Reform Treaty]]. Brown's opponents on both sides of the House, and in the press, suggested that ratification by Parliament was not enough and that a referendum should also be held. Labour's 2005 manifesto had pledged to give British public a referendum on the original [[EU Constitution]].{{cite news | title=Gordon Brown attacked on all sides for 'running away' from referendum | url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/politics/article2718086.ece | accessdate= 23 October 2007| publisher= Times Online| date=23 October 2007 | location=London | first=Francis | last=Elliott}}{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7023458.stm|title=Cameron attacks Brown on EU vote|publisher=BBC News|date=2 October 2007|accessdate=15 September 2008}} Brown argued that the Treaty significantly differed from the Constitution, and as such did not require a referendum. He also responded with plans for a lengthy debate on the topic, and stated that he believed the document to be too complex to be decided by referendum.{{cite news | title=Battle of the EU treaty to last for months | url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article2687253.ece | accessdate= 19 October 2007| publisher=Times Online| date=19 October 2007 | first1=Francis | last1=Elliott | first2=David | last2=Charter | location=London}} ===Drug policy=== During Brown's premiership, in October 2008, the [[Advisory Council on the Misuse of Drugs]] (ACMD) recommended to the then [[Home Secretary]] [[Jacqui Smith]] that [[cannabis]] remain classified as a [[Class C drug]].{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7845023.stm | work=BBC News | title=Debate over cannabis classification | date=31 October 2009 | accessdate=2 April 2010}} Acting against the advice of the Council, she chose to reclassify it as [[class B drug|class B]]. After Professor [[David Nutt]], the chair of the ACMD, criticised this move in a lecture in 2009, he was asked to step down by then Home Secretary [[Alan Johnson]].{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8334774.stm | work=BBC News | title=Cannabis row drugs adviser sacked | date=30 October 2009 | accessdate=2 April 2010}} Following his resignation, Professor Nutt said Gordon Brown had "made up his mind" to reclassify cannabis despite evidence to the contrary.Batty, David [http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/2009/oct/31/david-nutt-drugs-adviser-sacked Professor David Nutt warns resignations may result from prime minister's 'absurd' stance on reclassification] The Guardian, 31 October 2009 Gordon Brown had argued, "I don't think that the previous studies took into account that so much of the cannabis on the streets is now of a lethal quality and we really have got to send out a message to young people – this is not acceptable".[http://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKL2973937220080430 Brown says message must be sent on cannabis], Reuters, 20 April 2008Oates, John [http://www.theregister.co.uk/2008/04/29/brown_cannabis_science Brown opts for morality over science on 'lethal skunk'] The Register, 29 April 2008 Professor Nutt's predecessor at the ACMD, [[Michael Rawlins|Sir Michael Rawlins]], later said, "Governments may well have good reasons for taking an alternative view... When that happens, then the government should explain why it's ignoring the particular advice".{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8335189.stm|title=Sacked adviser criticises Brown|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=31 October 2009 | date=31 October 2009}} ===Global recession=== Brown's premiership coincided with the [[Late-2000s recession|global recession]], during which Brown called for fiscal action in an attempt to stimulate aggregate demand. Domestically, Brown's administration introduced measures including a bank rescue package worth around £500 billion (approximately $850 billion), a temporary 2.5% cut in Value Added Tax (Sales Tax)http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/7757854.stm | VAT tax reduction (dated December 2008 from the BBC website) and a "car scrappage" scheme.http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/8278679.stm | Car scrappage scheme extended (2009 BBC website) ===Plots against leadership=== In mid-2008, Brown's leadership was presented with a challenge as some MPs openly called for him to resign. This event was dubbed the 'Lancashire Plot', as two backbenchers from [[Local Government Act 1972|(pre-1974) Lancashire]] urged him to step down and a third questioned his chances of holding on to the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] leadership. Several MPs argued that if Brown did not recover in the polls by early 2009, he should call for a leadership contest. However, certain prominent MPs, such as [[Jacqui Smith]] and [[Bill Rammell]], suggested that Brown was the right person to lead Britain through its economic crisis.{{cite news | title=Cabinet backs Brown but 'Lancashire plot' sparks open warfare | url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/cabinet-backs-brown-but-lancashire-plot-sparks-open-warfare-879414.html | accessdate= 29 July 2008 | publisher=The Independent| first1=Nigel | last1=Morris | date=29 July 2008 | location=London}} In the Autumn, [[Siobhain McDonagh]], a MP and junior government whip, who during her time in office had never voted against the government,{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7613296.stm|title=Profile: Siobhain McDonagh|publisher=BBC News|date=12 September 2008|accessdate=14 September 2008}} spoke of the need for discussion over Brown's position. McDonagh was sacked from her role shortly afterwards, on 12 September. Whilst McDonagh did not state that she wanted Brown deposed, she implored the Labour party to hold a leadership election, she was sacked from her role shortly afterwards.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7613086.stm|title=Whip sacked over leader bid call|publisher=BBC News|date=12 September 2008|accessdate=14 August 2008}} McDonagh was supported by [[Joan Ryan]] (who applied, as McDonagh had, for leadership nomination papers, and became the second rebel to be fired from her job), [[Jim Dowd (politician)|Jim Dowd]], [[Greg Pope]], and a string of others who had previously held positions in government, made clear their desire for a contest.{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/politics/article4749182.ece|title=Ex-ministers join Gordon Brown rebellion|publisher=The Times|author=Jonathan Oliver, Marie Woolf|date=14 September 2008|accessdate=14 September 2008 | location=London}} In the face of this speculation over Brown's future, his ministers backed him to lead the party, and [[Harriet Harman]] and [[David Miliband]] denied that they were preparing leadership bids. After Labour lost the [[Glasgow East by-election, 2008|Glasgow East by-election]] in July, Harman, the deputy leader of the party, said that Brown was the "solution", not the "problem"; Home Secretary Smith, Justice Secretary [[Jack Straw]], Schools Secretary [[Ed Balls]] and Cabinet Office Minister [[Ed Miliband]] all re-affirmed their support for Brown.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7531576.stm|title=Harman denies planning leader bid|publisher=BBC News|date=29 July 2008|accessdate=14 September 2008}} The deputy Prime Minister under Blair, [[John Prescott]], also pledged his support.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7527725.stm|title=Prescott warns over PM challenge|publisher=BBC News|date=27 July 2008|accessdate=14 September 2008}} Foreign Secretary David Miliband then denied that he was plotting a leadership bid, when on 30 July, an article written by him in ''[[The Guardian]]'' was interpreted by a large number in the media as an attempt to undermine Brown. In the article, Miliband outlined the party's future, but neglected to mention the Prime Minister. Miliband, responded to this by saying that he was confident Brown could lead Labour to victory in the next general election, and that his article was an attack against the [[fatalism]] in the party since the loss of Glasgow-East.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7532691.stm|title=Miliband denies 'leadership' bid|publisher=BBC News|date=30 July 2008|accessdate=14 September 2008}} Miliband continued to show his support for Brown in the face of the challenge that emerged in September, as did Business Secretary [[John Hutton, Baron Hutton of Furness|John Hutton]], Environment Secretary [[Hilary Benn]], and Chief Whip [[Geoff Hoon]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7615274.stm|title=Miliband throws support behind PM|publisher=BBC News|date=14 September 2008|accessdate=14 September 2008}} On 6 January 2010, [[Patricia Hewitt]] and [[Geoff Hoon]] jointly called for a secret ballot on the future of Brown's leadership.{{cite news |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2010/jan/06/hoon-hewitt-gordon-brown-labour |title=Hewitt and Hoon's great gamble |publisher=The Guardian |date=6 January 2010 | location=London | first=Martin | last=Kettle | accessdate=3 May 2010}} The call received little support and the following day Hoon said that it appeared to have failed and was "over". Brown later referred to the call for a secret ballot as a "form of silliness".{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/8450375.stm |title=Gordon Brown says leadership challenge was 'silliness' |publisher=[[BBC News Online]]|date=10 January 2010}} ===By-elections and 2009 local and European elections=== [[File:G8brown.JPG|thumb|left|Gordon Brown meeting Russian President [[Vladimir Putin]] in 2006|alt=Gordon Brown shakes hands with Vladimir Putin]] In the local elections on 1 May 2008, Labour suffered their worst results in 40 years finishing in third place with a projected 24% share of the national vote.{{cite news | title = Labour suffers big council losses | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7372860.stm| work = BBC News | date = 2 May 2008 | accessdate=2 January 2010}} Subsequently the party has seen the loss of [[by-election]]s in [[Crewe and Nantwich by-election, 2008|Nantwich and Crewe]] and [[Henley by-election, 2008|Henley]] as well as slumps in the polls. A [[Glasgow East by-election, 2008|by-election in Glasgow East]] triggered by the resignation of [[David Marshall (UK politician)|David Marshall]] saw the Labour party struggle to appoint a candidate, eventually settling for [[Margaret Curran (politician)|Margaret Curran]], a sitting MSP in the [[Scottish Parliament]]. The SNP, Conservatives and Liberal Democrats have all derided the party for their disorganised nature with [[Alex Salmond]] commenting "This is their 'lost weekend' – they don't have a leader in Scotland, they don't have a candidate in Glasgow East, and they have a prime minister who refuses to come to the constituency".{{cite news|publisher=BBC News|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/7491574.stm|title=Labour MSP joins by-election race|accessdate=3 August 2008 | date=5 July 2008}} Labour lost the constituency to the [[Scottish National Party]]'s [[John Mason (Scottish politician)|John Mason]] who took 11,277 votes with Labour just 365 behind. The seat experienced a swing of 22.54%.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/glasgow_and_west/7522153.stm|title= SNP stuns Labour in Glasgow East|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=19 July 2009|date=25 July 2008 }} In the [[European Parliament elections, 2009 (United Kingdom)|European elections]], Labour polled 16% of the vote, finishing in third place behind the Conservatives and [[United Kingdom Independence Party]] (UKIP).{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/8088133.stm |title=Labour slumps to historic defeat |publisher=BBC News |date=8 June 2009 |accessdate=21 June 2009}} Voter apathy was reflected in the historically low turnout of around thirty three percent. In Scotland voter turnout was only twenty eight per cent. In the [[United Kingdom local elections, 2009|local elections]], Labour polled 23% of the vote, finishing in third place behind [[Conservative Party(UK)|Conservatives]] and [[Liberal Democrats]], with Labour losing control of the four councils it had held prior to the election.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/shared/bsp/hi/elections/local_council/09/html/region_999999.stm |title=Election 2009 | Councils A-Z |publisher=BBC News |date=7 June 2009 |accessdate=21 June 2009}} In a vote widely considered to be a reaction to the expenses scandal, the share of the votes was down for all the major parties; Labour was down one percent, the Conservative share was down five percent. The beneficiary of the public backlash was generally seen to be the minor parties, including the [[Green Party of England and Wales|Green Party]] and UKIP. These results were Labour's worst since World War II. Gordon Brown was quoted in the press as having said that the results were "a painful defeat for Labour", and that "too many good people doing so much good for their communities and their constituencies have lost through no fault of their own."{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/8088358.stm|title=Salmond hails historic Euro win|publisher=BBC News | date=8 June 2009 | accessdate=2 January 2010}} ===General election 2010=== [[File:Gordon Brown, University of Bradford.jpg|thumb|right|Gordon and Sarah Brown at the [[University of Bradford]] the day before the [[United Kingdom general election 2010|2010 Election]].]] {{Main|United Kingdom general election, 2010}} In April 2010, Brown asked the Queen to dissolve Parliament and call new elections, which included the first televised leadership debates in British History. The result of the election was a [[hung parliament]], laying the foundations for the first full coalition government since 1974 and only the second since the Grand Coalition during World War II that sat for almost 8 years. Brown was re-elected to serve as MP for Kirkcaldy & Cowdenbeath constituency on 6 May 2010 with 29,559 votes representing 64.5% of votes. ===Resignation=== {{further|[[Labour Party (UK) leadership election, 2010]]}} Brown announced on 10 May 2010 that he would stand down as Labour Leader, with a view to a successor being chosen before the next [[Labour Party Conference]] in September 2010.{{cite news |title=Gordon Brown 'stepping down as Labour leader'|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/election_2010/8672859.stm |work=[[BBC News]] |date=10 May 2010 |accessdate=10 May 2010}} The following day, negotiations between the Labour Party and the Liberal Democrats to form a coalition government failed. During the evening, Brown visited [[Buckingham Palace]] to tender his resignation as Prime Minister to [[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth II]] and to recommend that she invite the Leader of the Opposition, [[David Cameron]], to form a government. He resigned as leader of the Labour Party with immediate effect. ==Post-Prime Ministership== ===Return to the backbenches=== On 13 May 2010, in his first public appearance since leaving [[10 Downing Street]], two days after resigning as Prime Minister and Leader of the Labour Party, Brown confirmed he intended to stay on in Parliament, serving as a Labour [[Backbencher]], in order to serve the people of his [[Kirkcaldy and Cowdenbeath (UK Parliament constituency)|Kirkcaldy and Cowdenbeath constituency]].{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/8681018.stm |title=Brown to remain as backbench MP |publisher=BBC News |date=13 May 2010 |accessdate=14 May 2010 }} ===World Wide Web Foundation=== [[Sir Tim Berners-Lee]] worked with the UK government during Brown's premiership to publish government data as freely as possible on the internet in the [[data.gov.uk]] project. Berners-Lee subsequently invited Brown to become a board director of the World Wide Web Foundation to "advise the Web Foundation on ways to involve disadvantaged communities and global leaders in the development of sustainable programs that connect humanity and affect positive change".[http://www.webfoundation.org/2010/09/gordon-brown-joins-world-wide-web-foundation-board/ Former British Prime Minister Gordon Brown Joins World Wide Web Foundation’s Board of Directors], ''[[World Wide Web Foundation]]'' 2 September 2010. ===World Economic Forum role=== On 22 April 2011 it was announced that Brown would be taking on an unpaid advisory role at the [[World Economic Forum]].{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-13171942 | work=BBC News | title=Gordon Brown takes on World Economic Forum role | date=22 April 2011}} ===IMF speculation 2011=== In April 2011, media reports linked Brown with the role as the next Managing Director of the International Monetary Fund following the scheduled retirement of Dominique Strauss-Kahn.{{cite news| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1376712/Gordon-Brown-favourite-head-IMF-George-Osborne-stop-him.html | newspaper=Daily Mail | title=Brown 'clear favourite' to be next head of IMF but will Osborne fight to stop him? | date=14 April 2011 | location=London | first=Alex | last=Brummer}} Brown's successor and Leader of the Opposition, Ed Milliband, supported Brown for the role while the Prime Minister, David Cameron, voiced opposition to this.{{Cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/2011/apr/19/gordon-brown-not-most-appropriate-imf-cameron|newspaper=Guardian|title=Gordon Brown 'not most appropriate person' to head IMF, says Cameron|date=19 April 2011|accessdate=18 October 2011|location=London|first=Helene|last=Mulholland}} Following the arrest of Strauss-Kahn for alleged sexual assault in May 2011, and his subsequent resignation, these reports re-surfaced.{{cite news| url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/2011/may/20/gordon-brown-imf-strauss-kahn | newspaper=Guardian | title=Gordon Brown makes IMF pitch as race to succeed Strauss-Kahn intensifies | date=20 May 2011 |accessdate=18 October 2011 | location=London | first=Larry | last=Elliott}} Support for Brown among economists was mixed but British Government backing for his candidature was not forthcoming and instead supported Christine Lagarde—the eventual successful candidate—for the post.{{cite news|url=http://www.mirror.co.uk/news/top-stories/2011/05/24/economist-backs-gordon-brown-for-imf-top-job-115875-23152474|title=Economist backs Gordon Brown for IMF top job|newspaper=The Mirror|date=24 May 2011|accessdate=17 July 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://news.sky.com/home/world-news/article/15994318 |title=Brown 'Not Right' To Take Over IMF Top Job |date=19 May 2011 |publisher=Sky News |accessdate=14 October 2011 }}{{cite news|title=Germany, Britain back Lagarde to lead IMF|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/business/economy/germany-britain-back-lagarde-to-lead-imf/2011/05/21/AFVrri8G_story.html|accessdate=22 May 2011|newspaper=[[Washington Post]]|date=22 May 2011|first=Cecilia|last=Kang}} ===Other positions=== Brown was appointed as the inaugural 'Distinguished Leader in Residence' by New York University and has already taken part in discussions and lectures relating to the global financial crisis{{cite web|url=http://www.nyu.edu/about/news-publications/news/2011/04/06/former-uk-prime-minister-gordon-brown-discusses-the-role-of-cities-in-the-wake-of-the-2008-global-financial-crisis.html|title=Former UK Prime Minister discusses the role of cities in the wake of the 2008 global financial crisis|publisher=nyu.edu|date=11 April 2011|accessdate=17 July 2011}} and globalization.{{cite web|url=http://wagner.nyu.edu/news/newsStory.php?id=696 |title=Former UK Prime Minister on the Promise of Globalization|publisher=NYUWagner|date=15 December 2010|accessdate=17 July 2011}} ==Personal life and family== [[File:Gordon and Sarah Brown.jpg|right|thumb|Sarah Brown attending one of her husband's speeches]] Brown's early girlfriends included the journalist [[Sheena McDonald]] and [[Margarita of Romania|Princess Margarita]], the eldest daughter of exiled [[Michael of Romania|King Michael of Romania]]. At the age of 49, Brown married [[Sarah Brown (wife of Gordon Brown)|Sarah Macaulay]] in a private ceremony at his home in [[North Queensferry]], Fife, on 3 August 2000.{{cite news | title= Gordon and Sarah wed at home: | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/864413.stm | accessdate= 23 September 2007 | date=3 August 2000|work=BBC News|location=London}} On 28 December 2001 a daughter, Jennifer Jane, was born prematurely and died on 7 January 2002 one day after suffering a [[brain haemorrhage]].[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1380699/Jennifer-dies-in-their-arms.html Jennifer dies in their arms] Telegraph, 8 January 2002 They currently have two children, John Macaulay{{cite news|url=http://news.scotsman.com/gordonbrownsfamily/Chancellors-daughter-remembered-at-christening.2522714.jp|title=Chancellor's daughter remembered at christening service|publisher=The Scotsman | location=Edinburgh|first=Jenny|last=Morrison|date=23 April 2004}} and (James) Fraser. In November 2006, James Fraser was diagnosed with [[cystic fibrosis]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/6157891.stm|title=Brown's son has cystic fibrosis|publisher=BBC News|date=29 December 2006|accessdate=13 July 2009 | date=29 November 2006}} ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'' had learned of the situation in 2006 and published the story. In 2011 Brown stated he had wanted the details of his son's condition kept private and that the publication had left him "in tears".{{cite news |title= Gordon Brown attacks News International tactics |author= |url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-14119225 |newspaper= BBC News |date= 12 July 2011 |accessdate=12 July 2011}} The Sun said they approached Mr Brown and that discussion occurred with his colleagues who provided quotes to use in the article.{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-14164756|title=Guardian apologises to the Sun over Gordon Brown story|publisher=The BBC|date=15, July, 2011|accessdate=17 July 2011}} Sarah Brown rarely makes official appearances either with or without her husband. She is inevitably much sought after to give interviews.{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2007/05/12/nbrown512.xml|title=Wife will seek to stay out of the limelight|publisher=Daily Telegraph|date=12 May 2007|accessdate=10 June 2007 | location=London | first1=Andrew | last1=Pierce | first2=Auslan | last2=Cramb}} She is, however, patron of several charities and has written articles for national newspapers related to this.{{cite news|url=http://thescotsman.scotsman.com/maggiescentre/Why-I-want-you-to.2825970.jp|last=Brown|first=Sarah|authorlink=Sarah Brown (Prime Minister's wife)|title=Why I want you to get behind Maggie's|publisher=[[The Scotsman]]|date=11 November 2006|accessdate=25 May 2008}} At the 2008 Labour Party Conference, Sarah caused surprise by taking to the stage to introduce her husband for his keynote address.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7632115.stm|title=Sarah Brown steps into spotlight|accessdate=30 September 2008 | work=BBC News | date=23 September 2008}} Since then her public profile has increased.{{cite news | first= Rajini| last= Vaidyanathan| coauthors= |authorlink= | title=Glamorous Life of the PM's Wife | date=17 July 2009 | publisher= | url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/8155377.stm | pages = | accessdate = 14 September 2009 | language = | work=BBC News}} Gordon Brown has two brothers, John Brown and [[Andrew Brown (media strategist)|Andrew Brown]]. Andrew has been Head of Media Relations in the UK for the French-owned utility company [[EDF Energy]] since 2004.[http://www.guardian.co.uk/nuclear/article/0,,1817582,00.html The powerful business of promoting a nuclear future], Terry Macalister 11 July 2006, ''[[The Guardian]]'' Gordon Brown is also the brother-in-law of environmental journalist [[Clare Rewcastle Brown]]. Gordon wrote a piece for The Independent, supporting Clare's current environmental efforts on behalf of [[Sarawak]].{{cite news| url= http://www.independent.co.uk/environment/green-living/fight-for-the-borneo-rainforest-gordon-brown-celebrates-the-role-of-journalist-clare-rewcastle-2237427.html | title= Fight for the Borneo rainforest: Gordon Brown celebrates the role of journalist Clare Rewcastle |publisher= The Independent|date= 10 March 2011|accessdate= 13 March 2011|location=London}} Whilst [[Prime minister|PM]] Brown spent some of his spare time at [[Chequers]], the house often being filled with friends. The Browns have entertained local dignitaries like Sir Leonard Figg.{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/columnists/guest_contributors/article4386767.ece|title=Alice Thomson, ''No PM, However Dour, can Resist the Charms of a Stately Pile'', The Times, 24 July 2008 | location=London | date=24 July 2008 | accessdate=2 April 2010 | first=Deirdre | last=Hipwell}} Brown is also a friend of Harry Potter author [[J. K. Rowling]], who says of Brown "I know him as affable, funny and gregarious, a great listener, a kind and loyal friend."{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,1894410_1893847_1894201,00.html|title=Gordon Brown — The 2009 TIME 100|publisher=TIME Magazine|accessdate=1 May 2009|last=|first= | date=30 April 2009}} ==Religion== The son of a [[Church of Scotland]] [[minister (Christianity)|minister]], Brown has talked about what he calls his "[[moral compass]]"{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/gordon-brown-i-joined-this-party-as-a-teenager--its-values-are-my-moral-compass-454560.html|title= Gordon Brown: 'I joined this party as a teenager ... Its values are my moral compass'|publisher =The Independent|accessdate=26 October 2009| date=25 June 2007 | location=London}} and of his parents being his "inspiration".{{cite web|url=http://www.epolitix.com/latestnews/article-detail/newsarticle/gordon-brown-leadership-speech-in-full/?no_cache=1|title=Gordon Brown: Leadership speech in full|publisher=ePolitix.com|accessdate=26 October 2009}} He has, at least ostensibly, been keen to keep his religion a private matter.{{cite web|url=http://www.epolitix.com/latestnews/article-detail/newsarticle/profile-gordon-brown/?no_cache=1|title=Profile Gordon Brown|publisher=ePolitix.com|accessdate=28 September 2009}} According to the ''Guardian'', he is a member of the Church of Scotland.{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2009/sep/23/pope-benedict-to-visit-britain|title=Pope accepts Gordon Brown's invitation to visit Britain next year|date=24 September 2009|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=24 September 2009 | location=London | first=Patrick | last=Wintour}} In April 2009, Brown gave what was the first ever speech by a serving Prime Minister at [[St Paul's Cathedral]] in London. He referred to a 'single powerful modern sense demanding responsibility from all and fairness to all'. He also talked about the [[Christian doctrine]] of 'do to others what you would have them do unto you', which he compared to similar principles in [[Judaism]], [[Islam]], [[Hinduism]] and [[Sikhism]]. He went on, 'They each and all reflect a sense that we share the pain of others, and a sense that we believe in something bigger than ourselves—that we cannot be truly content while others face despair, cannot be completely at ease while others live in fear, cannot be satisfied while others are in sorrow", and continued, "We all feel, regardless of the source of our philosophy, the same deep moral sense that each of us is our brother and sisters' keeper... We cannot and will not pass by on the other side when people are suffering and when we have it within our power to help.'{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1166182/Brown-DOES-God-calls-new-world-order-sermon-St-Pauls.html|title=Brown DOES do God as he calls for new world order in sermon at St Paul's|publisher=Daily Mail|accessdate=26 October 2009 | location=London | first=James | last=Chapman | date=1 April 2009}} ==Socialism== Brown first thought of himself as being 'Labour' and his sense of social injustice was roused when he accompanied his father on visits around [[Kirkcaldy]] seeing the pain of unemployment and the misery of poverty and squalor as the mining and textile industries collapsed. Growing up he discovered [[R. H. Tawney|Tawney]], [[Robert Tressell|Tressell]], [[G. D. H. Cole|Cole]] and other socialist texts which inspired him. He also found inspiration in [[William Blake|Blake]] in poetry, [[Dennis Potter|Potter]] in drama, [[D. H. Lawrence|Lawrence]] in literature and the socialist leader [[James Maxton]] in Scottish history. These, he argues, fuelled his passion and activism, reinforcing his own political experience. For Brown the ethical basis of British socialism has several themes: the view that individuals are not primarily self-centered but are co-operative, that people are more likely to thrive in communities in which they play a full role and that people have talents and potential that the free market will not allow them to fully realise. In addition, one of the most enduring of Brown's themes is the commitment to equality.Gordon Brown (1995) The aim of the rose, The Independent on Sunday, 18 JuneBrown, Gordon (ed.); Wright, Tony (ed.) (1995). Values, Visions and Voices: An Anthology of Socialism. ==Titles, honours, and awards== ===Styles=== * Mr James Gordon Brown (1951–1982) * Dr James Gordon Brown (1982–1983) * Dr James Gordon Brown MP (1983–1996){{cite web |title=Hall of Fame – Gordon Brown |url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/wales/ps/sites/roughguide/hall_of_fame/pages/gordon_brown.shtml |date= |work= Ps |publisher= BBC Wales |accessdate=17 July 2009}} * The Right Honourable Dr James Gordon Brown MP (1996–present)"Ex-BBC chief and child health professor among life peers", ''The Guardian'', 15 June 1996, p. 6"Court Circular", ''The Times'', 24 July 1996 ===Honours=== In March 2009 Brown was named [[The Appeal of Conscience Foundation#World Statesman of the Year|World Statesman of the Year]] by the [[Appeal of Conscience Foundation]], an American organisation dedicated to promoting peace, [[human rights]] and understanding between [[religion|religious faiths]]. The award was presented by [[Rabbi]] [[Arthur Schneier]] who praised Brown's "compassionate leadership in dealing with the challenging issues facing humanity, his commitment to freedom, human dignity and the environment, and for the major role he has played in helping to stabilize the world's financial system".{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/2009/mar/03/brown-world-statesman|title= US foundation names Gordon Brown world statesman of the year|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=25 June 2009|accessdate=15 July 2009 | date=3 March 2009 | location=London}}{{cite web|url=http://www.appealofconscience.org/news/article.cfm?id=100195|title=ACF to Honor British Prime Minister Gordon Brown with 2009 World Statesman Award|publisher=Appeal of Conscience Foundation|accessdate=15 August 2009}}[http://www.appealofconscience.org/news/article.cfm?id=100222 The Right Honorable Gordon Brown MP, Prime Minister of the United Kingdom of Great Britain & Northern Ireland receives Appeal of Conscience Foundation 2009 World Statesman Award] Appeal of Conscience Foundation, 22 September 2009 ==Depictions in popular culture== In keeping with its tradition of having a comic strip for every Prime Minister ''[[Private Eye (magazine)|Private Eye]]'' featured a comic strip, ''The Broonites'' (a parody of ''[[The Broons]]''), parodying Brown's government.
